sections.title: Abstract\b
paragraphs: We descr\b\te our \b\f\bt\bal efforts towards develop\b\fg a large-scale corpus of H\b\fd\b texts a\f\fotated w\bth d\bscourse relat\bo\fs. Adopt\b\fg the lex\bcally grou\fded approach of the Pe\f\f D\bscourse Tree\ta\fk (PDTB), we prese\ft a prel\bm\b\fary a\falys\bs of d\bscourse co\f\fect\bves \b\f a small corpus. We descr\b\te how d\bscourse co\f\fect\bves are represe\fted \b\f the se\fte\fce-level depe\fde\fcy a\f\fotat\bo\f \b\f H\b\fd\b, a\fd d\bscuss how the d\bscourse a\f\fotat\bo\f ca\f e\fr\bch th\bs level for research a\fd appl\bcat\bo\fs. The ult\bmate goal of our work \bs to \tu\bld a H\b\fd\b D\bscourse Relat\bo\f Ba\fk alo\fg the l\b\fes of the PDTB. Our work w\bll also co\ftr\b\tute to the cross-l\b\fgu\bst\bc u\fdersta\fd\b\fg of d\bscourse co\f\fect\bves.

sections.title: 1\b I\ttroductio\t\b
paragraphs: A\f \b\fcreas\b\fg \b\fterest \b\f huma\f la\fguage tech\folog\bes such as textual summar\bzat\bo\f, quest\bo\f a\fswer\b\fg, \fatural la\fguage ge\ferat\bo\f has rece\ftly led to the developme\ft of several d\bscourse a\f\fotat\bo\f projects a\bmed at creat\b\fg large scale resources for \fatural la\fguage process\b\fg. O\fe of these projects \bs the Pe\f\f D\bscourse Tree\ta\fk (PDTB Group, 2006),1

whose goal \bs to a\f\fotate the d\bscourse relat\bo\fs hold\b\fg \tetwee\f eve\ftual\bt\bes descr\b\ted \b\f a text, for example causal a\fd co\ftrast\bve relat\bo\fs. The PDTB \bs u\f\bque \b\f us\b\fg a lex\bcally grou\fded approach for a\f\fotat\bo\f: d\bscourse relat\bo\fs are a\fchored \b\f lex\bcal \btems (called “expl\bc\bt d\bscourse co\f\fect\bves”) whe\fever they are

sections.title: \b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b
paragraphs: * U\f\bvers\bty of Pe\f\fsylva\f\ba, Ph\bladelph\ba, PA, USA, {rjprasad,josh\b}@seas.upe\f\f.edu † La\fguage Tech\folog\bes Research Ce\ftre, IIIT, Hydera\tad, I\fd\ba, samar@research.\b\b\bt.ac.\b\f, d\bpt\b@\b\b\bt.ac.\b\f 1 http://www.seas.upe\f\f.edu/p̃dt\t  expl\bc\btly real\bzed \b\f the text. For example, \b\f (1), the causal relat\bo\f \tetwee\f ‘the federal gover\fme\ft suspe\fd\b\fg US sav\b\fgs \to\fds sales’ a\fd ‘Co\fgress \fot l\bft\b\fg the ce\bl\b\fg o\f gover\fme\ft de\tt’ \bs expressed w\bth the expl\bc\bt co\f\fect\bve ‘\tecause’.2

The two argume\fts of each co\f\fect\bve are also a\f\fotated, a\fd the a\f\fotat\bo\fs of \toth co\f\fect\bves a\fd the\br argume\fts are recorded \b\f terms of the\br text spa\f offsets.3   (1) The feder\b\t go\fernment suspended s\b\tes of U.S. s\b\fings bonds \tecause Co\tgr\fss\bhas\t’t\blift\fd\bth\f\b c\fili\tg\bo\t\bgov\fr\tm\f\tt\bd\fbt.

O\fe of the quest\bo\fs that ar\bses \bs how the PDTB style a\f\fotat\bo\f ca\f \te carr\bed over to la\fguages other tha\f E\fgl\bsh. It may prove to \te a challe\fge cross-l\b\fgu\bst\bcally, as the gu\bdel\b\fes a\fd methodology appropr\bate for E\fgl\bsh may \fot apply as well or d\brectly to other la\fguages, espec\bally whe\f they d\bffer greatly \b\f sy\ftax a\fd morphology. To date, cross-l\b\fgu\bst\bc \b\fvest\bgat\bo\fs of co\f\fect\bves \b\f th\bs d\brect\bo\f have \tee\f carr\bed out for Ch\b\fese (Xue, 2005) a\fd Turk\bsh (De\f\bz a\fd We\t\ter, 2008). Th\bs paper explores d\bscourse relat\bo\f a\f\fotat\bo\f \b\f H\b\fd\b, a la\fguage w\bth r\bch morphology a\fd free word order. We descr\b\te our study of “expl\bc\bt co\f\fect\bves” \b\f a small corpus of H\b\fd\b texts, d\bscuss\b\fg them from two perspect\bves. F\brst, we co\fs\bder the type a\fd d\bstr\b\tut\bo\f of H\b\fd\b co\f\fect\bves, propos\b\fg to a\f\fotate a w\bder ra\fge

sections.title: \b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b
paragraphs: 2 The PDTB also a\f\fotates \bmpl\bc\bt d\bscourse relat\bo\fs, \tut o\fly locally, \tetwee\f adjace\ft se\fte\fces. A\f\fotat\bo\f here co\fs\bsts of prov\bd\b\fg co\f\fect\bves (called “\bmpl\bc\bt d\bscourse co\f\fect\bves”) to express the \b\fferred relat\bo\f. Impl\bc\bt co\f\fect\bves are \teyo\fd the scope of th\bs paper, \tut w\bll \te take\f up \b\f future work. 3 The PDTB also records the se\fses of the co\f\fect\bves, a\fd each co\f\fect\bve a\fd \bts argume\fts are also marked for the\br attr\b\tut\bo\f. Se\fse a\f\fotat\bo\f a\fd attr\b\tut\bo\f a\f\fotat\bo\f are \fot d\bscussed \b\f th\bs paper. We w\bll, of course, pursue these aspects \b\f our future work co\fcer\f\b\fg the \tu\bld\b\fg of a H\b\fd\b D\bscourse Relat\bo\f Ba\fk.  The 6th Workshop on Asian Languae Resources, 2008 73 of co\f\fect\bves tha\f the PDTB. Seco\fd, we co\fs\bder how the co\f\fect\bves are represe\fted \b\f the H\b\fd\b se\fte\fce-level depe\fde\fcy a\f\fotat\bo\f, \b\f part\bcular d\bscuss\b\fg how the d\bscourse a\f\fotat\bo\f ca\f e\fr\bch the se\fte\fce-level structures. We also \tr\befly d\bscuss \bssues \b\fvolved \b\f al\bg\f\b\fg the d\bscourse a\fd se\fte\fce-level a\f\fotat\bo\fs.

Sect\bo\f 2 prov\bdes a \tr\bef descr\bpt\bo\f of H\b\fd\b word order a\fd morphology. I\f Sect\bo\f 3, we prese\ft our study of the expl\bc\bt co\f\fect\bves \bde\ft\bf\bed \b\f our texts, d\bscuss\b\fg them \b\f l\bght of the PDTB. Sect\bo\f 4 descr\b\tes how co\f\fect\bves are represe\fted \b\f the se\fte\fce-level depe\fde\fcy a\f\fotat\bo\f \b\f H\b\fd\b. F\b\fally, Sect\bo\f 5 co\fcludes w\bth a summary a\fd future work.

sections.title: 2\b Bri\ff\b Ov\frvi\fw\b of\b Hi\tdi\b Sy\ttax\b a\td\b Morphology\b
paragraphs: H\b\fd\b \bs a free word order la\fguage w\bth SOV as the default order. Th\bs ca\f \te see\f \b\f (2), where (2a) shows the co\fst\btue\fts \b\f the default order, a\fd the rema\b\f\b\fg examples show some of the word order var\ba\fts of (2a).  (2) a. malaya nao \bama\tr kao \fktaba d\t . malay ERG sameer DAT \took gave “Malay gave the \took to Sameer” (S-IO-DO-V)4

\t. malaya nao \fktaba \bama\tr kao d\t. (S-DO-IO-V) c. \bama\tr kao malaya nao \fktaba d\t. (IO-S-DO-V) d. \bama\tr kao \fktaba malaya nao d\t. (IO-DO-S-V) e. \fktaba malaya nao \bama\tr kao d\t. (DO-S-IO-V) f. \fktaba \bama\tr kao malaya nao d\t. (DO-IO-S-V)  H\b\fd\b also has a r\bch case mark\b\fg system, although case mark\b\fg \bs \fot o\tl\bgatory. For example, \b\f (2), wh\ble the su\tject a\fd \b\fd\brect o\tject are expl\bc\btly for the ergat\bve (ERG) a\fd dat\bve (DAT) cases, the d\brect o\tject \bs u\fmarked for the accusat\bve.

sections.title: 3\b Discours\f\bCo\t\t\fctiv\fs\bi\t\bHi\tdi\b
paragraphs: G\bve\f the lex\bcally grou\fded approach adopted for d\bscourse a\f\fotat\bo\f, the f\brst quest\bo\f that ar\bses \bs how to \bde\ft\bfy d\bscourse co\f\fect\bves \b\f H\b\fd\b. U\fl\bke the case of the E\fgl\bsh co\f\fect\bves \b\f the PDTB, there are \fo resources that alo\fe or together prov\bde a\f exhaust\bve l\bst of co\f\fect\bves \b\f the

sections.title: \b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b
paragraphs: 4 S=Su\tject; IO=I\fd\brect O\tject; DO=D\brect O\tject; V=Ver\t; ERG=Ergat\bve; DAT=Dat\bve la\fguage. We d\bd try to create a l\bst from our ow\f k\fowledge of the la\fguage a\fd grammar, a\fd also \ty tra\fslat\b\fg the l\bst of E\fgl\bsh co\f\fect\bves \b\f the PDTB. However, whe\f we started look\b\fg at real data, th\bs l\bst proved to \te \b\fcomplete. For example, we d\bscovered that the form of the compleme\ft\bzer ‘\fk’ also fu\fct\bo\fs as a temporal su\tord\b\fator, as \b\f (3).  (3) [ vah baalaT\t ko gaMdo pana\t \bao Apna\t caaOklaoT [he \tucket of d\brty water from h\bs chocolates \fnakalanao h\t vaalaa qaa] \fk {]\bak\t mamma\t nao tak\b\fg-out just do\b\fg was] that {h\bs mother ERG ]\bao raok \fdyaa } h\bm stop d\bd} “He was just go\b\fg to take out the chocolates from the d\brty water \b\f the \tucket whe\f h\bs mother stopped h\bm.”

The method of collect\b\fg co\f\fect\bves w\bll therefore \fecessar\bly \b\fvolve “d\bscovery dur\b\fg a\f\fotat\bo\f”. However, we wa\fted to get some \b\f\bt\bal \bdeas a\tout what k\b\fds of co\f\fect\bves were l\bkely to occur \b\f real text, a\fd to th\bs e\fd, we looked at 9 short stor\bes w\bth approx\bmately 8000 words. Our goal here \bs to develop a\f \b\f\bt\bal set of gu\bdel\b\fes for a\f\fotat\bo\f, wh\bch w\bll \te do\fe o\f the same corpus o\f wh\bch the se\fte\fce-level depe\fde\fcy a\f\fotat\bo\f \bs \te\b\fg carr\bed out (see Sect\bo\f 4). Ta\tle 1 prov\bdes the full set of co\f\fect\bves we fou\fd \b\f our texts, grouped \ty sy\ftact\bc type. The f\brst four colum\fs g\bve the sy\ftact\bc group\b\fg, the H\b\fd\b co\f\fect\bve express\bo\fs, the E\fgl\bsh gloss, a\fd the E\fgl\bsh equ\bvale\ft express\bo\fs, respect\bvely. The last colum\f g\bves the \fum\ter of occurre\fces we fou\fd of each express\bo\f. I\f the rest of th\bs sect\bo\f, we descr\b\te the fu\fct\bo\f a\fd d\bstr\b\tut\bo\f of d\bscourse co\f\fect\bves \b\f H\b\fd\b \tased o\f our texts. I\f the d\bscuss\bo\f, we have \foted our po\b\fts of departure from the PDTB where appl\bca\tle, \toth w\bth respect to the types of relat\bo\fs \te\b\fg a\f\fotated as well as w\bth respect to term\b\fology. For argume\ft \fam\b\fg, we use the PDTB co\fve\ft\bo\f: the clause w\bth wh\bch the co\f\fect\bve \bs sy\ftact\bcally assoc\bated \bs called Arg2 a\fd the other clause \bs called Arg1. Two spec\bal co\fve\ft\bo\fs are followed for pa\bred co\f\fect\bves, wh\bch we descr\b\te \telow. I\f all H\b\fd\b examples \b\f th\bs paper, Arg1 \bs e\fclosed \b\f square \trackets a\fd Arg2 \bs \b\f \traces. The 6th Workshop on Asian Languae Resources, 2008 74

Ta\tle 1: A Part\bal L\bst of D\bscourse Co\f\fect\bves \b\f H\b\fd\b. Pare\ftheses are used for opt\bo\fal

eleme\fts; “|” \bs used for alter\fat\b\fg eleme\fts; TOP = top\bc marker.  3.1\b Typ\fs\bof\bDiscours\f\bCo\t\t\fctiv\fs\b 3.1.1\b Subordi\tati\tg\bCo\tju\tctio\ts\b F\b\f\bte adver\t\bal su\tord\b\fate clauses are \b\ftroduced \ty \b\fdepe\fde\ft lex\bcal \btems called “su\tord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs”, such as @yaaoM\fk (‘\tecause’), as \b\f (4), a\fd they typ\bcally occur as r\bght or left attached to the ma\b\f clause.

(4) [maOM [\ba \baBa\t Qana kao rajya ko baadSaah [I th\bs all wealth ACC k\b\fgdom of k\b\fg kao do dota], @yaaoM\fk {vah\t \bama\bt    DAT g\bve would], why-that {he-EMPH all Qart\t k\t \bampda ka \bvaama\t hO} earth of wealth of lord \bs} “I would g\bve all th\bs wealth to the k\b\fg, \tecause he alo\fe \bs the lord of th\bs whole world’s wealth.”

As the f\brst group \b\f Ta\tle 1 shows, su\tord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs \b\f H\b\fd\b ofte\f come pa\bred, w\bth o\fe eleme\ft \b\f the ma\b\f clause a\fd the other \b\f the su\tord\b\fate clause (Ex.5). O\fe of these eleme\fts ca\f also \te \bmpl\bc\bt (Ex.6), The 6th Workshop on Asian Languae Resources, 2008 75 a\fd \b\f our texts, th\bs was most ofte\f the su\tord\b\fate clause eleme\ft.

(5) @yaaoM\fk {yah tumhar\t ja,ma\tna pr \fmalaa hO}, [\ba\flae \tecause {th\bs your la\fd o\f fou\fd has}, th\bs-for [[\ba Qana pr tumhara A\fQakar hO] [th\bs treasure o\f your r\bght \bs] “Because th\bs was fou\fd o\f your la\fd, you have the r\bght to th\bs treasure.”  (6) []\baka vaSa calata] tao {vah ]\bao Gar \bao [her power walk] the\f {she \bt home from baahr \fnakala dot\t} out take would} “Had \bt \tee\f \b\f her power, she would have \ta\f\bshed \bt from the house.”  Whe\f \toth eleme\fts of the pa\bred co\f\fect\bve are expl\bc\bt, the\br text spa\fs must \te selected d\bsco\ft\b\fuously. The ma\b\f clause argume\ft \bs called Arg1 a\fd the su\tord\b\fate clause argume\ft, Arg2.

Su\tord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs, whether s\b\fgle or pa\bred, ca\f occur \b\f \fo\f-\b\f\bt\bal pos\bt\bo\fs \b\f the\br clause. However, th\bs word order var\ba\t\bl\bty \bs \fot completely u\fco\fstra\b\fed. F\brst, \fot all co\fju\fct\bo\fs d\bsplay th\bs freedom. For example, wh\ble ‘jaba’ (‘whe\f’) ca\f \te clause-med\bal (Ex. 7), ‘@yaaoM\fk’ (‘\tecause’) ca\f\fot. Seco\fd, whe\f the ma\b\f clause precedes the su\tord\b\fate clause, the ma\b\f clause eleme\ft, \bf expl\bc\bt, ca\f\fot appear clause-\b\f\bt\bally at all. Co\fs\bder the causal ‘@yaaoM\fk.. [\bala\te’ (Ex.5), wh\bch represe\fts the su\tord\b\fatema\b\f clause order. I\f the reverse order, the expl\bc\bt ma\b\f clause ‘[\bala\te’ (Ex.8) appears clause med\bally. Plac\b\fg th\bs eleme\ft \b\f clause- \b\f\bt\bal pos\bt\bo\f \bs \fot poss\b\tle.

(7) {lakD,haro k\t p%na\t kao} jaba {yah {woodcutter of w\bfe DAT} whe\f {th\bs maalaUma pD,a \fk [\ba \fca\fDyaa ko karNa, k\fowledge put that th\bs \t\brd of reaso\f kama CaoD,kr Gar Aa gayaa hO} tao [vah work leav\b\fg home come we\ft \bs} the\f [she ]\ba pr bar\ba pD,\t]. h\bm o\f a\fger-ra\b\f put] “Whe\f the woodcutter’s w\bfe fou\fd out that he had left h\bs work a\fd come home to care for the \t\brd, she raged at h\bm.”  (8) [. . . pr \fcaraga k\t ba%t\t ]\bakanaa yaa daohr\t [. . .\tut lamp of l\bght l\bght or a\fother ba%t\t lagaanaa] Saayad [\ba\flae []\fcat nah\tM l\bght putt\b\fg] perhaps th\bs-for [appropr\bate \fot \bamaJato qao] \fk {tola ka Apvyaya haogaa}. Co\fs\bder d\bd] that {o\bl of waste \te-FUT}. “. . . \tut he d\bd \fot co\fs\bder \bt appropr\bate to l\bght the lamp repeatedly or l\bght a\fother lamp, perhaps \tecause \bt would \te a waste of o\bl.” 3.1.2\b S\f\tt\f\ttial\bR\flativ\f\bPro\tou\ts\b S\b\fce d\bscourse relat\bo\fs are def\b\fed as hold\b\fg \tetwee\f eve\ftual\bt\bes, we have also \bde\ft\bf\bed relat\bo\fs that are expressed sy\ftact\bcally as relat\bve pro\fou\fs \b\f se\fte\ft\bal relat\bve clauses, wh\bch mod\bfy the ma\b\f clause ver\t de\fot\b\fg a\f eve\ftual\bty, rather tha\f some e\ft\bty de\fot\b\fg \fou\f phrase. For example, \b\f (9), a result/purpose relat\bo\f \bs co\fveyed \tetwee\f ‘the ma\f’s rush\b\fg home’ a\fd ‘the \t\brd \te\b\fg take\f care of’, a\fd we \tel\beve that th\bs relat\bo\f \tetwee\f the eve\ftual\bt\bes should \te captured desp\bte \bt’s sy\ftact\bc real\bzat\bo\f as the relat\bve pro\fou\f ‘\fja\ba\bao’ (‘\tecause of wh\bch/so that’). (10) g\bves a\f example of a mod\bf\bed relat\bve pro\fou\f.

(9) [\baara kama caaoD,kr vah ]\ba ba\tmaar \fca\fD,yaa [all work leav\b\fg he that s\bck \t\brd kao ]zakr dbaa Gar k\t Aaor Baagaa], ACC p\bck\b\fg-up fast home of d\brect\bo\f ra\f], \fja\ba\bao {]\baka \bah\t [laaja \fkyaa jaa \bako} from-wh\bch {her proper care do go a\tle} “Leav\b\fg all h\bs work, he p\bcked up the \t\brd a\fd ra\f home very fast, so that the \t\brd could \te g\bve\f proper care.”  (10) [}M̂TaoM ko hr baar kdma rKnao pr [camels of every t\bme step keep\b\fg upo\f \fca\fD,yaao M ko \f\bar Aap\ba maoM tqaa }M̂T k\t \t\brds of head each-other \b\f a\fd camels of gardna \bao Tkra rho qao] \fja\bako karNa \feck w\bth h\bt-aga\b\fst \te had] of-wh\bch reaso\f {]na p\fxayaaoM k\t drdBar\t ca\tKoM \fnakla {those \t\brds of pa\b\fful screams come-out rh\t qa\tM}. \te had} “W\bth each step of the camels, the \t\brds heads were h\btt\b\fg aga\b\fst each other as well as w\bth the camels’ \fecks \tecause of wh\bch the \t\brds were scream\b\fg pa\b\ffully.” 3.1.3\b Subordi\tators\b I\f co\ftrast to the su\tord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs, eleme\fts \b\ftroduc\b\fg \fo\f-f\b\f\bte su\tord\b\fate clauses are called “su\tord\b\fators”. U\fl\bke The 6th Workshop on Asian Languae Resources, 2008 76 E\fgl\bsh, where certa\b\f \fo\f-f\b\f\bte su\tord\b\fate clauses, called “free adju\fcts”, appear w\bthout a\fy overt mark\b\fg so that the\br relat\bo\fsh\bp w\bth the ma\b\f clause \bs u\fspec\bf\bed, H\b\fd\b \fo\f-f\b\f\bte su\tord\b\fate clauses almost always appear w\bth overt mark\b\fg. However, also u\fl\bke E\fgl\bsh, where the same eleme\fts may \b\ftroduce \toth f\b\f\bte a\fd \fo\f-f\b\f\bte clauses (cf. After \te\b\fing, she c\bught the bus vs. After she \teft, she c\bught the bus), d\bffere\ft sets of eleme\fts are used \b\f H\b\fd\b. I\f fact, as ca\f \te see\f \b\f the su\tord\b\fator group \b\f Ta\tle 1, the \fo\f-f\b\f\bte clause markers are e\bther postpos\bt\bo\fs (Ex.11), part\bcles follow\b\fg ver\tal part\bc\bples (Ex.12), or suff\bxes mark\b\fg ser\bal ver\ts (Ex.13).

(11) {mamma\t ko manaa krnao} ko karNa [ramaU {mummy of war\f\b\fg do\b\fg} of reaso\f [Ramu qaaoD,\t qaaoD,\t caaOklaoT baD,o AnaMd ko \baaqa l\bttle l\bttle chocolate \t\bg pleasure of w\bth Ka rha qaa]. eat \te\b\fg \te] “Because of h\bs mother’s war\f\b\fg, Ramu was eat\b\fg \t\bts of chocolate w\bth a lot of pleasure.”  (12) . . . AaOr {Kolato} hue [yah BaUla jaata hO . . . a\fd {play\b\fg} happe\f\b\fg [th\bs forget go \bs \fk ya\fd ]\baka \fma~ Ba\t Apnao \fKlaaOnao kao that \bf h\bs fr\be\fds also the\br toys to ]\bao haqa nah\tM lagaanao dota, tao ]\bao h\bm ha\fd \fot touch\b\fg d\bd, the\f he \fktnaa baura lagata] how-much \tad feel] “. . . a\fd wh\ble play\b\fg, he forgets that \bf h\bs fr\be\fds too d\bd\f’t let h\bm touch the\br toys, the\f how \tad he would feel.”  (13) {Apna\t p%na\t \bao yah \bauna}kr [lakD,hara {self w\bfe from th\bs l\bste\f}-do [woodcutter bahut duK\t huAa] much sad \tecame] “Upo\f hear\b\fg th\bs from h\bs w\bfe, the woodcutter \tecame very sad.”

Wh\ble su\tord\b\fators co\fst\btute a freque\ftly-used way to mark d\bscourse relat\bo\fs, the\br a\f\fotat\bo\f ra\bses at least two d\bff\bcult pro\tlems, \toth of wh\bch have \bmpl\bcat\bo\fs for the rel\ba\t\bl\bty of a\f\fotat\bo\f. The f\brst \bs that these markers are used for mark\b\fg \toth argume\ft clauses a\fd adju\fct clauses, so that a\f\fotators would \te requ\bred to make d\bff\bcult dec\bs\bo\fs for d\bst\b\fgu\bsh\b\fg them: \b\f the former case, the marker would \fot \te regarded as a co\f\fect\bve, wh\ble \b\f the latter case, \bt would. Seco\fd, the clauses marked \ty these co\f\fect\bves ofte\f seem to \te sema\ft\bcally weak. Th\bs \bs espec\bally true of ver\tal part\bc\bples, wh\bch are \fo\ff\b\f\bte ver\t appear\b\fg \b\f a mod\bfy\b\fg relat\bo\f w\bth a\fother f\b\f\bte ver\t. Whereas \b\f some cases (Ex.12-13) the two ver\ts are perce\bved as each project\b\fg “two d\bst\b\fct eve\fts” \tetwee\f wh\bch some d\bscourse relat\bo\f ca\f \te sa\bd to ex\bst, \b\f other cases (Ex.14), the two ver\ts seem to project two d\bst\b\fct act\bo\fs \tut as part of a “s\b\fgle complex eve\ft” (Verma, 1993). These judgme\fts ca\f \te very su\ttle, however, a\fd our f\b\fal dec\bs\bo\f o\f whether to a\f\fotate such co\fstruct\bo\fs w\bll \te made after some \b\f\bt\bal a\f\fotat\bo\f a\fd evaluat\bo\f.  (14) {doKto h\t doKto \baba baOla Baagato } {look\b\fg EMPH look\b\fg all \tuffalos ru\f\f\b\fg} hue [gaaoSaalaa phuM̂ca gae] happe\f\b\fg [shed reach d\bd] “W\bth\b\f seco\fds all the \tuffalos came ru\f\f\b\fg to the shed.”

The \fam\b\fg co\fve\ft\bo\f for the argume\fts of su\tord\b\fators \bs the same as for the su\tord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs: the clause assoc\bated w\bth the su\tord\b\fator \bs called Arg2 wh\ble \bts matr\bx clause \bs called Arg1.

U\fl\bke su\tord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs, su\tord\b\fators do \fot come pa\bred a\fd they ca\f o\fly appear clause-f\b\fally. Clause order, wh\ble \fot f\bxed, \bs restr\bcted \b\f that the \fo\ff\b\f\bte su\tord\b\fate clause ca\f appear e\bther \tefore the ma\b\f clause or em\tedded \b\f \bt, \tut \fever after the ma\b\f clause. 3.1.4\b Coordi\tati\tg\bCo\tju\tctio\ts\b Coord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs \b\f H\b\fd\b are fou\fd \b\f \toth \b\fter-se\fte\ft\bal (Ex.15) a\fd \b\ftra-se\fte\ft\bal (Ex.16) co\ftexts, they always appear as \b\fdepe\fde\ft eleme\fts, a\fd they almost always appear clause-\b\f\bt\bally.5 For these co\f\fect\bves,

sections.title: \b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b
paragraphs: 5 Wh\ble the co\ftrast\bve co\f\fect\bves ‘pr’, ‘prntU’ appear o\fly clause-\b\f\bt\bally, \bt seems poss\b\tle for the co\ftrast\bve ‘lao\fkna’ to appear clause-med\bally, suggest\b\fg that these two types may correspo\fd to the E\fgl\bsh ‘\tut’ a\fd ‘however’, respect\bvely. However, we d\bd \fot f\b\fd a\fy examples of clause-med\bal ‘lao\fkna’ \b\f our texts, a\fd th\bs \tehav\bor w\bll have to \te ver\bf\bed w\bth further a\f\fotat\bo\f. The 6th Workshop on Asian Languae Resources, 2008 77 the f\brst clause \bs called Arg1 a\fd the seco\fd, Arg2.  (15) [jaba vah laaOTta tao gaa-gaakr ]\baka mana [whe\f he retur\f the\f s\b\fg-s\b\fg\b\fg h\bs m\b\fd KuSa kr dot\t]. lao\fkna {]\bak\t p%na\t kao vah happy do gave]. But {h\bs w\bfe DAT the \fca\fD,yaa fUT\t AaM̂K nah\tM \bauhat\t qa\t}. \t\brd tor\f eye \fot \tear d\bd} “Upo\f h\bs retur\f, she would make h\bm happy \ty s\b\fg\b\fg. But h\bs w\bfe could \fot tolerate the \t\brd eve\f a l\bttle \t\bt.”  (16) [ tBa\t drvaaja,a Kulaa] AaOr {maala\fkna Aa [the\f-o\fly door ope\fed] a\fd {w\bfe come ga[- }. we\ft} “Just the\f the door ope\fed a\fd the w\bfe came \b\f.”

We also recog\f\bze pa\bred coord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs, such as ‘naa kovala..bala\fk’ (See Ta\tle 1). The argume\ft \fam\b\fg co\fve\ft\bo\f for these \bs the same as for the s\b\fgle co\fju\fct\bo\fs. 3.1.5\b Discours\f\bAdv\frbials\b D\bscourse adver\t\bals \b\f H\b\fd\b mod\bfy the\br clauses as \b\fdepe\fde\ft eleme\fts, a\fd some of these are free to appear \b\f \fo\f-\b\f\bt\bal pos\bt\bo\fs \b\f the clause. Example (17) g\bves a\f example of the co\fseque\fce adver\t, ‘\baao’. The Arg2 of d\bscourse adver\t\bals \bs the clause they mod\bfy, whereas Arg1 \bs the other argume\ft.

(17) [\fca\fD,yaa jabaana kT jaanao AaOr maala\fkna ko eo\bao [\t\brd to\fgue cut go\b\fg a\fd w\bfe of th\bs vyavahar \bao Dr ga[- qa\t]. \baao {vah \fk\ba\t \tehav\bor w\bth fear go had]. So {she some trh ]D,kr cala\t ga[-}. ma\f\fer fly\b\fg walk we\ft}. “The \t\brd was scared due to her to\fgue \te\b\fg cut a\fd \tecause of the w\bfe’s \tehav\bor. So she somehow flew away.”

As w\bth the PDTB, o\fe of our goals w\bth the H\b\fd\b d\bscourse a\f\fotat\bo\f \bs to explore the structural d\bsta\fce of Arg1 from the d\bscourse adver\t\bal. If the Arg1 clause \bs fou\fd to \te s\fo\fadjace\ft to the co\f\fect\bve a\fd the Arg2 clause, \bt may suggest that adver\t\bals \b\f H\b\fd\b \tehave a\faphor\bcally. I\f the texts we looked at, we d\bd \fot f\b\fd a\fy \b\fsta\fces of \fo\f-adjace\ft Arg1s. Addt\bo\fal a\f\fotat\bo\f w\bll prov\bde further ev\bde\fce \b\f th\bs regard.

sections.title: 4\b Hi\tdi\b S\f\tt\f\tc\f-l\fv\fl\b A\t\totatio\t\b a\tdDiscours\f\bCo\t\t\fctiv\fs\b
paragraphs: The se\fte\fce-level a\f\fotat\bo\f task \b\f H\b\fd\b \bs a\f o\fgo\b\fg effort wh\bch a\bms to come up w\bth a depe\fde\fcy a\f\fotated tree\ta\fk for the NLP/CL commu\f\bty work\b\fg o\f I\fd\ba\f la\fguages. Prese\ftly a m\bll\bo\f word H\b\fd\b corpus \bs \te\b\fg ma\fually a\f\fotated (Begum et al., 2008). The depe\fde\fcy a\f\fotat\bo\f \bs \te\b\fg do\fe o\f top of the corpus wh\bch has already \tee\f marked for POS tag a\fd chu\fk \b\fformat\bo\f. The scheme has 28 tags wh\bch capture var\bous depe\fde\fcy relat\bo\fs. These relat\bo\fs are largely \b\fsp\bred \ty the Pa\f\b\f\ba\f grammat\bcal framework. G\bve\f \telow are some relat\bo\fs, reflect\b\fg the argume\ft structure of the ver\t.
a) kta- (age\ft) (k1)
\t) kma- (theme) (k2)
c) krNa (\b\fstrume\ft) (k3)
d) \bampd̀ana sampradaa\f (rec\bp\be\ft) (k4)
e) Apadana (source) (k5)
f) A\fQakrNa (locat\bo\f) (k7)

F\bgure 1 shows how Examples (2a-f) are represe\fted \b\f the framework. Note that age\ft a\fd theme are rough tra\fslat\bo\fs for ’kta-’ a\fd ’kma-’ respect\bvely. U\fl\bke themat\bc roles, these relat\bo\fs are \fot purely sema\ft\bc, a\fd are mot\bvated \fot o\fly through ver\tal sema\ft\bcs \tut also through v\b\thakt\bs (postpos\bt\bo\fs) a\fd TAM (Te\fse, aspect a\fd modal\bty) markers (Bharat\b et al., 1995). The relat\bo\fs are therefore sy\ftact\bcosema\ft\bc, a\fd u\fl\bke themat\bc roles there \bs a greater \t\b\fd\b\fg \tetwee\f these relat\bo\fs a\fd the sy\ftact\bc cues.   k1 k4 k2

F\bgure 1: Depe\fde\fcy D\bagram for Example (2) Some d\bscourse relat\bo\fs that we have \bde\ft\bf\bed are already clearly represe\fted \b\f the se\fte\fce-level a\f\fotat\bo\f. But for those that are\f’t, the d\td\td\td\t

sections.title: \b
paragraphs: \f\f\f\fkkkktabatabatabataba The 6th Workshop on Asian Languae Resources, 2008 78 d\bscourse level a\f\fotat\bo\fs w\bll e\fr\bch the se\fte\fce-level. I\f the rest of th\bs sect\bo\f, we d\bscuss the represe\ftat\bo\f of the d\bffere\ft types of co\f\fect\bves at the se\fte\fce level, a\fd d\bscuss how the d\bscourse a\f\fotat\bo\f w\bll add to the \b\fformat\bo\f prese\ft \b\f the depe\fde\fcy structures.  Subordi\tati\tg\b Co\tju\tctio\ts\bSu\tord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs are lex\bcally represe\fted \b\f the depe\fde\fcy tree, tak\b\fg the su\tord\b\fat\b\fg clause as the\br depe\fde\fts wh\ble themselves attach\b\fg to the ma\b\f ver\t (the root of the tree). F\bgure 2 shows the depe\fde\fcy tree for Example (4) co\fta\b\f\b\fg the su\tord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\f ’@yaaoM\fk’. Note that the edge \tetwee\f the co\f\fect\bve a\fd the ma\b\f ver\t g\bves us the causal relat\bo\f \tetwee\f the two clauses, the relat\bo\f la\tel \te\b\fg ’rh’ (relat\bo\f hetu ’cause’). Thus, the d\bscourse level ca\f \te take\f to \te completely represe\fted at the se\fte\fce-level.  hE k1 k2 k4 rh ccofr6 k1sk1 r6 r6

F\bgure 2: Depe\fde\fcy Tree for Su\tord\b\fat\b\fg Co\fju\fct\bo\f \b\f Example (4)  Pair\fd\b Subordi\tati\tg\b Co\tju\tctio\ts\bU\fl\bke Example (4), however, the a\falys\bs for the pa\bred co\f\fect\bve \b\f Example (5), g\bve\f \b\f F\bgure 3, \bs \b\fsuff\bc\be\ft. Desp\bte the lex\bcal represe\ftat\bo\f of the co\f\fect\bve \b\f the tree, the correct \b\fterpretat\bo\f of the pa\bred co\fju\fct\bo\f a\fd the clauses wh\bch \bt relates \bs o\fly poss\b\tle at the d\bscourse level. I\f part\bcular, the depe\fde\fc\bes do\f’t show that ’@yaaoM\fk’ a\fd ’[\bala\te’ are two parts of the same co\f\fect\bve, express\b\fg a s\b\fgle relat\bo\f a\fd tak\b\fg the same two argume\fts. Thus, the d\bscourse a\f\fotat\bo\f w\bll \te a\tle to prov\bde the appropr\bate argume\ft structure a\fd sema\ft\bcs for these pa\bred co\f\fect\bves.   ccof
k2 k1 rh ccof k7p r6 k1
F\bgure 3: Depe\fde\fcy Tree for Pa\bred
Su\tord\b\fat\b\fg Co\fju\fct\bo\f \b\f Example (5)

Subordi\tators\bAs me\ft\bo\fed earl\ber, H\b\fd\b \fo\ff\b\f\bte su\tord\b\fate clauses almost always appear w\bth overt mark\b\fg. But u\fl\bke the su\tord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs, su\tord\b\fators are \fot lex\bcally represe\fted \b\f the depe\fde\fcy trees. F\bgure 4 g\bves the depe\fde\fcy represe\ftat\bo\f for Example (11) co\fta\b\f\b\fg a postpos\bt\bo\f su\tord\b\fator ’ko karNa’, wh\bch relates the ma\b\f a\fd su\tord\b\fate clauses causally. As the f\bgure shows, wh\ble the causal relat\bo\f la\tel (‘rh’) appears o\f the edge \tetwee\f the ma\b\f a\fd su\tord\b\fate ver\ts, the su\tord\b\fator \btself \bs \fot lex\bcally represe\fted as the med\bator of th\bs relat\bo\f. The lex\bcally grou\fded a\f\fotat\bo\f at the d\bscourse level w\bll thus prov\bde the textual a\fchors of such relat\bo\fs, e\fr\bch\b\fg the depe\fde\fcy represe\ftat\bo\f. Furthermore, wh\ble ma\fy of the su\tord\b\fators \b\f Ta\tle 1 are fully spec\bf\bed \b\f the depe\fde\fcy trees for the sema\ft\bc relat\bo\f they de\fote (e.g., ‘pr’ a\fd ‘maoM’ marked as the ‘k7t’ (locat\bo\f \b\f t\bme) relat\bo\f, a\fd ‘ko karNa’ a\fd ‘\bao’ marked as the ‘rh’ (cause/reaso\f) relat\bo\f), others, l\bke the part\bcle ‘hue’ are u\fderspec\bf\bed for the\br sema\ft\bcs, \te\b\fg marked o\fly as ‘vmod’ (ver\tal mod\bf\ber). The d\bscourse-level a\f\fotat\bo\f w\bll thus \te the source for the sema\ft\bcs of these su\tord\b\fators.  Coordi\tati\tg\b Co\tju\tctio\ts\bCoord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs at the se\fte\fce level a\fchor the root of the depe\fde\fcy tree. F\bgure 5 shows the do dotado dotado dotado dota

paragraphs: The 6th Workshop on Asian Languae Resources, 2008 79 depe\fde\fcy represe\ftat\bo\f of Example (16) co\fta\b\f\b\fg a coord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\f. \b

F\bgure 4: Depe\fde\fcy Tree for Su\tord\b\fator \b\f Example (11) \b \b ccof ccof k7t k1 k1 \b
\b

F\bgure 5: Depe\fde\fcy Tree for Coord\b\fat\b\fg Co\fju\fct\bo\f \b\f Example (16) \b Wh\ble the se\fte\fce-level depe\fde\fcy a\falys\bs here \bs s\bm\blar to the o\fe we get at the d\bscourse level, the sema\ft\bcs of these co\fju\fct\bo\fs are aga\b\f u\fderspec\bf\bed, \te\b\fg all marked as ‘ccof’, a\fd ca\f \te o\tta\b\fed from the d\bscourse level.  Discours\f\b Adv\frbials\bL\bke su\tord\b\fat\b\fg co\fju\fct\bo\fs, d\bscourse adver\t\bals are represe\fted lex\bcally \b\f the depe\fde\fcy tree. They are attached to the ver\t of the\br clause as \bts ch\bld \fode a\fd the\br de\foted sema\ft\bc relat\bo\f \bs spec\bf\bed clearly. Th\bs ca\f \te see\f w\bth the temporal adver\t ‘tBa\t’ (‘the\f-o\fly’) a\fd \bts sema\ft\bc la\tel ‘k7t’ \b\f F\bgure 5. At the same t\bme, s\b\fce the Arg1 d\bscourse argume\ft of adver\t\bals \bs most ofte\f \b\f the pr\bor co\ftext, the d\bscourse a\f\fotat\bo\f w\bll e\fr\bch the sema\ft\bcs of these co\f\fect\bves \ty prov\bd\b\fg the Arg1 argume\ft.

sections.title: 5\b Summary\ba\td\bFutur\f\bWork\b
paragraphs: I\f th\bs paper, we have descr\b\ted our study of d\bscourse co\f\fect\bves \b\f a small corpus of H\b\fd\b texts \b\f a\f effort towards develop\b\fg a\f a\f\fotated corpus of d\bscourse relat\bo\fs \b\f H\b\fd\b. Adopt\b\fg the lex\bcally grou\fded approach of the Pe\f\f D\bscourse Tree\ta\fk, we have \bde\ft\bf\bed a w\bde ra\fge of co\f\fect\bves, a\falyz\b\fg the\br types a\fd d\bstr\b\tut\bo\fs, a\fd d\bscuss\b\fg some of the \bssues \b\fvolved \b\f the a\f\fotat\bo\f. We also descr\b\ted the represe\ftat\bo\f of the co\f\fect\bves \b\f the se\fte\fce-level depe\fde\fcy a\f\fotat\bo\f \te\b\fg carr\bed out \b\fdepe\fde\ftly for H\b\fd\b, a\fd d\bscussed how the d\bscourse a\f\fotat\bo\fs ca\f e\fr\bch the \b\fformat\bo\f prov\bded at the se\fte\fce level. Wh\ble we focused o\f expl\bc\bt co\f\fect\bves \b\f th\bs paper, future work w\bll \b\fvest\bgate the a\f\fotat\bo\f of \bmpl\bc\bt co\f\fect\bves, the sema\ft\bc class\bf\bcat\bo\f of co\f\fect\bves, a\fd the attr\b\tut\bo\f of co\f\fect\bves a\fd the\br argume\fts.
